page.title: 19LANGUAGE
page.content: Apart from the "classless" BBC style pronunciationin wide use in Southend there are two main styles of speaking which can be said to be local dialects.One is rooted in the historical movement of families from London's East End to the area which began with the introduction in the late 19th Century of the railway line from Fenchurch Street.This was popular for cockney day trippers who speedily moved into the locality.Their manner of speaking is readily identifiable by the dropping of H's,K's,and G's and the merging of TH's into F's.The other is also distinctive and comes from the farming communities in the villages which surrounded the town,identifiable by the elongated vowel sounds and the distinct pronunciation of TH's,T's and other consonants.
